questions.question: This is a question on the binomial distribution. Consider the experiment in which 10 lights are independently and random switched on, each with some probability $p\in(0,1)$. Which of the following describes the probability of seeing exactly $4$ lights on, after this random experiment? (note that $\binom{n}{k}$ refers to the binomial coefficient.

explanations.a: Incorrect Answer. It is true that there are $\binom{10}{4}$ ways to switch on exactly $4$ of the $10$ lights. Do check the probability of getting one such configuration, which seems to be the source of your error.
explanations.b: Correct Answer! There are $\binom{10}{4}$ ways to switch on exactly $4$ of the $10$ lights, each possible way is obtained with probability $p^4(1-p)^6$
explanations.c: Incorrect answer. You have to account for the number of ways to pick the possible configurations of having $4$ of the lights on, and the remaining $6$ off, first. Then, calculate the probability of each such configuration (recall that you have to account for the lights which are off also, in this calculation).
explanations.d: Incorrect answer. You have to account for the number of ways to pick the possible configurations of having $4$ of the lights on, and the remaining $6$ off, first. Then, calculate the probability of each such configuration (recall that you have to account for the lights which are off also, in this calculation).
explanations.e: Well, one of them is the correct answer.

questions.question: Consider two random variables $X$ and $Y$, taking values in sets $\mathcal{X}=\{0,a\}$ and $\mathcal{Y}=\{b,c,5\}$, with conditional probability satisfying the following equations. $$p_{Y|X}(b|a)=0.2, p(c|a)=0.4, p(c|0)=0.6, p(5|0)=0.1.$$ What are the values of $p_Y(5)$ and $p_Y(b)$, if $p_X(0)=0.3$?

explanations.a: Incorrect answer. Try using the total probability rule, i.e., $p_Y(y)=\sum_{x\in\mathcal{X}}p_{Y|X}(y|x)p_X(x)$.
explanations.b: Correct answer! $p_Y(5)$ is calculated as follows: $p_Y(5)=p_{Y|X}(5|0)p_X(0)+p_{Y|X}(5|a)p_X(a)=0.1\times 0.3+(1-0.2-0.4)\times(1-0.3)=0.03+0.28=0.31$.
explanations.c: Incorrect answer. Try using the total probability rule, i.e., $p_Y(y)=\sum_{x\in\mathcal{X}}p_{Y|X}(y|x)p_X(x)$.
explanations.d: Incorrect answer. Try using the total probability rule, i.e., $p_Y(y)=\sum_{x\in\mathcal{X}}p_{Y|X}(y|x)p_X(x)$.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the distribution of a Bernoulli random variable $X$?

explanations.a: Wrong answer. This is a valid distribution, but it is not a Bernoulli distribution, it is the Binomial distribution.
explanations.b: Incorrect answer. A Bernoulli random variable takes only two values.
explanations.c: Correct answer! A Bernoulli random variable takes two possible values (most often represented as $0,1$), and the probabilities should sum to $1$.
explanations.d: Incorrect answer! A Bernoulli random variable does take only two possible values (most often represented as $0,1$. But their probabilities should sum to $1$.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the distribution of a Gaussian random variable $X$ with mean $5$ and variance $5$?

questions.question: Consider a $4$-length Gaussian random vector $\boldsymbol{X}=(X_1,X_2,X_3,X_4)$, with each component generated independently and identically (i.e., $X_i$s are i.i.d), from a Gaussian distribution with mean $2$ and variance $4$. Select the expression that describes the probability density function of $\boldsymbol{X}$.

explanations.b: Incorrect answer. The random variables are independent, so their joint probability density function is the product of their individual probability density functions, i.e., $p_{\boldsymbol X}(x_1,x_2,x_3,x_4)=\prod_{i=1}^4 p_{X_i}(x_i)$. Now, each $p_{X_i}(x_i)$ is a Gaussian p.d.f. with mean=$2$ and variance = $4$. Use this to arrive at the right answer.
